name: Introduction to Archaeology
description: This course provides an overview of archaeology as a field of study and its relationship to other disciplines within the humanities. Topics may include archaeological methods, ethics, and the interpretation of material culture.

name: World Archaeology
description: This course explores the archaeology of various regions and cultures around the world, including the rise of complex societies, social organization, and the development of written language.

name: Art and Archaeology of the Ancient World
description: This course examines the art and artifacts of ancient societies, and explores the relationship between art and archaeology as sources of information about the past

name: Archaeology of the Americas
description: This course focuses on the archaeology of the Americas, including the pre-Columbian societies of North, Central, and South America.

name: Environmental Archaeology
description: This course examines the relationship between human societies and the environment throughout history, with an emphasis on the use of environmental data in archaeological research.

name: Anthropology of Food
description: This course explores the cultural, social, and environmental factors that shape food systems and culinary practices around the world.

name: Archaeological Theory and Methods
description: This course explores the theoretical approaches and methods used by archaeologists to study the past. Topics may include archaeological ethics, excavation techniques, and data analysis.

name: Historical Archaeology
description: This course examines the archaeology of the recent past, with a focus on the material culture and built environment of colonial and industrial societies.

name: Archaeology of Death and Burial
description: This course examines the archaeological and cultural aspects of death and burial practices, including funerary art, the material culture of death, and the relationship between mortuary practices and social organization.

name: Archaeology and Social Justice
description: This course explores the intersections of archaeology and social justice, including the role of archaeology in the construction of national identity, issues of cultural heritage, and the representation of marginalized communities in archaeological research.

name: Fieldwork in Archaeology
description: This course provides hands-on training in archaeological field methods, including survey, excavation, and laboratory analysis.
